explanation:
snprintf — Needed to know exact contract (how many bytes it writes, null-termination guarantees when given size=16) to determine whether snprintf(Buffer, sizeof(Buffer), "[%5s]", ...) can ever write beyond Buffer[16].

strlen — Used on both Buffer and OutputMessage; strlen reads until a NUL byte, so we must know its semantics and that the strings passed are NUL-terminated to ensure no out-of-bounds reads.

UtAssert_GetCaseTypeAbbrev — The returned C-string is formatted into Buffer via "%5s". We must know whether this function always returns a NUL-terminated string and its maximum possible length (so we can reason about snprintf output size and potential truncation/overflows).

OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl — Called with strlen(Buffer), a literal " \n", " ", and MsgLen along with OutputMessage. Need the prototype/behavior to confirm it reads only the supplied length bytes (and does not itself assume or read beyond a buffer’s terminator), and that passing strlen(Buffer) is appropriate.

UtAssert_DoReport, UtAssert_Message, UtMessage, UtPrintx, UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport, UtAssert_Abort, UT_BSP_Setup, UT_BSP_StartTestSegment — These are the call sites that pass OutputMessage into UT_BSP_DoText (per the static call graph). To prove there is no out-of-bounds access when calling strlen(OutputMessage) or indexing OutputMessage[MsgLen-1], we must inspect how each caller constructs or forwards OutputMessage (are they always NUL-terminated strings, can MsgLen be trusted, could OutputMessage be NULL or non-terminated?).

(Reason omitted: other symbols in the function such as OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl and the TermModeBits/enum constants do not affect string-bounds semantics, so they are not required for this MISRA string-bounds analysis.)
